_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary:



1. Accidental Release Program and Emergency Response Policies at the Facility:



The management and staff at the Pryor Chemical Plant are strongly committed to safety for our employees, the public, and the environment.  This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as process design, installation, operating procedures, system maintenance, and employee training.  It is a facility policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent releases of regulated substances where possible.



2. The facility and the Regulated Substances Handled:



The Pryor Chemical Plant manufactures nitrogenous fertilizer.  The facility processes Natural Gas to produce Anhydrous Ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is the only regulated substance present at the facility.  Anhydrous ammonia is used in the following processes or areas of the process: ammonia manufacturing, ammonia storage and loading, nitric acid (56%) manufacturing, nitric acid (56%) storage and urea manufacturing. The largest quantity of anhydrous ammonia stored at the facility is 15,000 tons or 30,000,000 lbs. 



3. General Accidental Release Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:



Our facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements per 40 CFR Part 68. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that are in place at our facility:



Process Safety Information:

Pryor Chemical Company maintains detailed safety information for chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment designs for all processes.



Process Hazard Analysis

Our facility previously conducted a comprehensive PHA while the facility was operational to identify hazards associated with the processes and ensure proper controls of these hazards.  The most recent PHA/Update was conducted on April 3, 2014.  The methodology used to conduct the recent analysis was HAZOP.

The PHA is conducted by qualified personnel with expertise in the process operations/engineering and PHA areas.  The PHA will be revalidated on a regular interval of every 5 years.



Operational Procedures

The Pryor Chemical Company maintains up-to-date written operating procedures to assure that facility activities are conducted safely. These procedures address various modes or portions of the process.  Some of the key procedures include: product loading, initial startup, normal process operations, normal process shutdown, and emergency shutdown.  These procedures are regularly reviewed and updated as necessary.  The procedures are available to all operators involved in the respective processes.



Training

The Pryor Chemical Company has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees are competent in the operational procedures associated with their job duties. Training will be conducted prior to facility start up, and refresher training will be provided every year, or more frequently as needed. 



Mechanical Integrity

The facility performs documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operation. Process equipment inspected by these checks include at a minimum: storage tanks, pressure vessels, piping systems, loading areas, relief and vent systems, key valves, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps.   Maintenance is completed by qualified personnel.  Equipment deficiencies identified during maintenance inspections are corrected in a timely manner.



Management of Change

Written procedures are in place to manage changes in processes, equipment, and chemical storage or transfer. Personnel whose job tasks are affected by these changes are made aware of the changes in a timely manner.



Pre-Start Up Reviews

Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes or modifications are conducted as a regular practice.  The latest PSSR was conducted June 23, 2014 and covered the Co2 plant.



Compliance Audits

As

a company, audits are regularly conducted at company facilities.   This facility has audits conducted on a regular basis. Generally, audits are conducted every year.  Corrective actions based upon audit findings are implemented in a timely manner.



Incident Investigation

Pryor Chemical Company investigates all incidents which resulted in or could have resulted in a release of a regulated substance. These investigations are competed to determine root-cause and to implement corrective actions to prevent future incidents or near-misses.  All reports are retained for at least 5 years.



Employee Participation

Pryor Chemical Company knows that process safety management and accident prevention must be a team effort in order to be a success. Employees are encouraged to be knowledgeable about the facility's RMP program, which is accessible to all employees and to provide input on accident prevention practices.



Contractors

Contractors are hired by the company to conduct specialized services to the facility.  Prior to selecting a contractor, the Pryor Chemical Company completes a thorough evaluation of the company's safety performance.  Only contractors that meet our company's safety expectations are hired to provide services.  Contractors are informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.



4. Five-Year Accident History:



A total of twenty-nine (29) accidents/releases occured at the facility within the past five (5) years.



The worst accident/release occured on February 6, 2014 where a work order was issued to cut out and replace a water line damged due to freezing water. A safe work permit was issued and errantly stated that no lock out tag out was needed.  The water line was directly connected to an ammonia transfer line which was used for water injection into ammonia truck loading.  Due to the errant permit, there was no isolation and/or clearing completed prior to issuing the permits.  The

transfer line remained full of liquid anhydrous ammonia under 75psig pressure.  



Maintenance began working on the damaged line and as the mechanic removed the bonnett of the 2" frozen valve pressure was released.  The pressure of the ammonia caused a backflow of anhydrous ammonia into the water line and out throught the bonnett of the valve.  The spray of anhydrous ammonia hit the unprotected employee in the face causing chemical burns and environmental release of over 400 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  The employee was life flighted to Tulsa Hillcrest Burn Unit, injuries were far less than initially speculated and the employee was released the following day.



The environmental release of 400 pounds of anhydrous ammonia impacted Highway 412B temporarily shutting down traffic. No evacuations of any neighboring facilities was warranted.    



5. Emergency Response Program:



Pryor Chemical Company has a written emergency response plan for implementation during an accidental release of regulated materials.  The response plan contains emergency response aspects such as first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification to local emergency response agencies and the public, and post incident procedures.  The Pryor Fire Department is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which our emergency response activities are coordinated.  The latest Emergency Response Drill was conducted on December 4, 2013 and was audited by an outside contractor.



This facility has a Plant Wide Emergency Notification System consisting of a Whelen Vortex 3 emergency notification siren to update our emergency action plan. It is a remote wireless activated rotating siren to enhance the facility's Emergency Action Plan centered in the facility and at an elevation of 60 feet.

 

All Operators and Supervisors are equipped with a Radio Communication System consisting of 44 hand held radios to assist in employee communication. This also assists with emergency communications in

the case of a plant upset, an issue at a neighboring facility, or a weather emergency.  



6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



Pryor Chemical Company plans to continue improving and enhancing our safety program.  The facility is currently allocating funds for a full Digital Control System (DCS) in all major units.  Improved safety control and shut down devices which will allow for more computer based decision making which reduces the chances for human error.  In conjunction, the facility is going through process development and implementing a more stringent safety based culture.  To support this, the facility is currently in expansion of fire protection systems, fall protection systems, and has recently created a training coordinator position working with hourly employees.
